author: oaklandmatt
content:
Haha just relaying my experience. If you're sending to a mastering engineer it's a whole different conversation.

Always think about what you're trying to accomplish at any given stage. Then go after that goal. 

I used to spend too much time on sonics in writing sessions. I should have been solely focused on finding emotional magic. Now  I am just trying to inspire the artists and writers around me, I'll deal with the sonics later. Much better results.

I also used to fully mix-as-I-go, which painted me into a corner with gain staging and eq. Now when I get to the end of the process, I often pull things back and rebuild my levels so there's headroom and I can make that exciting production translate.

Different approaches for different parts of the process.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I would rule out the Izotope production bundle (Ozone is fine). I think Izotope is the least musical and hit-or-miss of the options. It's not bad, but it's not as fun to use as the other options, and I think that has an effect on your results.

Both the FabFilter Mastering bundle and Soundtoys bundle are great and you wouldn't go wrong with either pick. But they occupy different niches: FabFilter is clean and surgical while Soundtoys is all about injecting vibe and coloration and doesn't include anything remotely surgical.

I guess if you can only pick one I'd start with Soundtoys for the vibe and the way it would expand the sonic palette for your production work. Your DAW is going to have some perfectly capable EQ's and compressors to tide you over until you're ready for FabFilter.

Put another way, your production work is upstream of your mixing work and will influence the sound of your records more.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Nailed it Will. Split mono is a step in my mix prep sequence. Efficient method goes like this:

PT Downmixer stock plugin is the one for this (it collapses stereo channels to mono) - flip the phase of one side in the GUI and save that as your user default. If you insert your Downmixer on a faux stereo track, it’ll immediately silence it, so you can happily split and delete what you don’t need. 

(Check the meters though, sometimes ambience or other subtle stereo info isn’t very audible unless cranked.)

If the stereo track contains slightly panned mono information, pushing/pulling either of the faders in Downmixer will quickly get it to cancel, and you can note how much extra gain you need to add or subtract when level matching in the final step (below). Obviously if it’s deliberately panned info, you can either just leave the track stereo or match the pan position by ear (I prefer to do this because I like mono channels to behave like mono channels, and also half the CPU you’d use on a stereo track).

Finally, use clip gain to add 3dB to the resulting mono channel, and obviously pan it centre. This makes up for the level change according to default pan laws in Tools (-3dB).

author: Rollmottle
content: For production and mixing, Soundtoys all the way. For finishing, my money would go to FabFilter.

author: cian riordan
content: Hi Rae, these are awesome headphones but -- like any closed back headphone -- it's going to be hard to get a real sense of how things are going translate in the real world..  especially when it comes to low end. Everything on headphones is going to sound clear and direct, when that may not be the case coming through speakers. Checking stuff on some decent monitors in a decent room -- or even in your car --  is always the best way to know if things sound off or not. If you're stuck with headphones, something open back like a Sennheiser 600 will give you a less-hyped, more honest picture of your mix. They're also much less fatiguing to work on for long periods of time! But even to this day with my nice setup, I'm always checking the low end in different places... In my car, I'll know within 10 seconds of listening if things are where they're supposed to be or not.

author: Adam Thein

author: Rollmottle
content: I don’t think you can form a fully realized point of view without also understanding the what and why of what makes something an industry “standard.” You have to level set yourself against the baseline first before making an informed choice to deviate. Free plugins might totally be the thing for you, but you don’t know what you don’t know yet.

author: ALXCPH
content: Not to overstep, but I’m convinced it has to do with trying to keep the sound waves bouncing off the wall behind your speakers as in phase as possible. The further from the wall the bigger the delay before it combines with the forward moving sound waves.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zack Hames yes! Play with short delays and short verbs and slaps with low pass eq. H3000 has some great stereoizing chorus type effects too. 

I just did a super dry vocal that had delay and verb like this. I used waves supertap with left and right slightly different but super short delay times. Almost phasing. Barely blended in at -20dB. Then I used Valhalla Vintage Verb on the small ambience setting at like 4%. It widens the vocal and gives it space without sounding at all "wet"

author: Edsel Holden
content:
Very similar to Cal - but a long time ago someone told me to seek out full Rez waves of songs and use a HPF and LPF to see where they sat things in the frequency spectrum. 

Some songs the cymbals will go away when you filter below 10k, others you will need to filter to 5-6k.

Do the same on the lows filter and see what goes away. 

It’s very similar to what cal said but all you need is any EQ. And your listening for what goes away. I still do it sometimes. It’s a great practice.

author: Isaac Diskin
content: Any basic digital multimeter that you can get at Harbor Freight, Home Depot etc will do the trick! If you generate tones (sin waves) in your DAW or with an external device you can measure AC voltages at the various points you are interested in, and calibrate if need be. It’s important to understand what various decibel levels translate to in voltage, as that is what you would be measuring. For example, +4dBu = 1.228 Volts, and -10dBV = 0.316 Volts. But like the other answer said, unless you need to calibrate your outputs for a specific reason, you will be fine connecting various pieces of pro-audio gear as long as you pay attention to the gain staging and adjust gain as necessary so there’s no clipping. And if you need to interface with a consumer level device you’d probably be better off getting a bump-box or something of the like.

author: cian riordan
content: Your results will almost always be attributed to your skills! In this case, while I'd focus my attention on getting some reps in on various mixing projects, there's certainly room to grow in your equipment stable. Headphones are a great starting point and will likely continue to be useful down the road, but mixing on speakers helps you make things translate better to the real world (car & home stereos, public spaces, etc). So a pair of decent entry level monitors would be my next purchase. It will also prove useful for collaborating with other folks down the road as you can all hear the same thing from the same source.

One other thing about paid plugins from large companies - you can count on Waves or UAD, Soundtoys, Izotope all updating their tools on newer OS.  Some (definitely not all) free plugs are made by people starting out in developing plugins and they might move on to other things.

Actually in the middle of this situation now where a single dev plugin was used on a track and I can’t even buy the license anymore.

author: LAPhill
content:
Are you looking for resources on writing/production, or mixing? Just like with the record side, there's so much noise from bedroom composers and people that have zero real-world experience. And as Ruairi is always saying, even the people with real success often can't teach what they know. Maybe I'm a bit cranky after an 8 hour delay at the airport yesterday, but Spitfire has gotten quite good at creating "tutorial" videos that are thinly veiled advertisements, and many of their libraries are the equivalent of one-knob plugins or CLA vocals. Selling paint-by-numbers solutions to naïve kids who want to get into scoring (They're far from the only ones guilty of this). But to focus on some of the channels I think are actually worth their salt:

8-Bit Music Theory: https://www.youtube.com/@8bitMusicTheory/videos
Can be a bit basic at times, but he talks a lot about structure which, IMO, is becoming a lost art in modern scoring.

Anne-Kathrin Dern: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWJg1w7F3PKPbSpEF2YOejVjWAg-KcM3Z
Not the biggest name out there, but she has a no-bullshit way of explaining things about orchestration and theory that is clear and concise. As far as "teachers," I think she's a good one.

Alan Meyerson Waves Sessions: https://youtu.be/h9jZqn5lnw4
I hesitate to include this. I know for a fact that Alan swapped out a bunch of his go-to plugins to make everything a Waves product. I haven't watched this in awhile, but it's a good insight into how he sets up a big mix session and why he makes some of his decisions. He's also playing to the camera/audience some, so this is a your-mileage-may-vary recommendation.

McGowen Soundworks: https://www.youtube.com/@McGowanSoundworks/featured
Phil knows his shit, and goes pretty deep breaking down a few actual mixes, which is pretty rare to find.

If I think of others, I'll report back. Hope that helps

author: Deleted User
content: To my ears M50s sound very congested, especially in comparison to their direct competition - Beyer 770s(I own both). The transients(which for me are absolutely crucial to hear when producing or mixing) are almost inaudible on the M50s, while decently audible on the 770s. I do not find the M50s or the 770s even close to "well balanced", they both are a bit too budget for that distinction(they both have extreme presence peaks at their respective frequencies). I know someone who is very happy with the Shure SRH940s and Shure 1840s for critical listening(same drivers, I think). The M50s and 770s are both pretty much unusable in the low end under 50-60hz for me, I don't feel they translate well there. A few mastering engineers use the Blue closed-back headphones as a low-end reference, they would probably be worth a try. Audeze stuff is pretty good for transient response, but more expensive.

author: Zack Hames
content: So I’m not crazy! I went to Emotiva Stealth 8s. They don’t make them anymore, nearly no one uses them either and not easy to find now so it’s probably not a great rec, even though I love them. One is out of commission so I’m using genelec 1032a’s with sonarworks. I started working on genelecs when I got my new job, and genuinely my mixes translated 100% more on those and they’re not even the best monitors. Sonarworks takes out the chunky low mid thing and adds more high end and low end which I like. It depends on the room/setup too. I think you can’t go wrong with any upgrade from the Yamahas. I wouldn’t buy genelec 1032s, they’re just what my studio has.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Also beyond “fixing” the best thing i ever learned for drum mixing was drum bus compression, and using saturation on close mics.

My usual chain is this:
All kick and snare mics get some sort of eq if needed. Then I’ll put fab filter Saturn 2 and saturate the high end at around 700hz.

The I’ll bus all the drums to an aux. then I’ll usually do this:
Tape saturation (waves J37)
Parallel drum compression with a mix knob (fast release, slow attack) I use the kush audio AR-1, I used to use the waves abbey road mastering plugin. 

Sometimes I’ll use wavesfactory Spectre to boost highs and lows after all that. Maybe soundtoys Sie-Q to boost midrange.

author: chadwahlbrink
content: In regards to 32-bit, I try to stick with 32bit until Mastering. This is mainly out of an "abundance of caution," but basically, it's theoretically possible to have rounding errors/quantization distortion (granted at like -128dB) when bouncing between the 32-bit processing within the DAW and other processing like izotope RX or even just bouncing stems from one person to another. Note - there is also a settting in pro tools to "always use 32-bit for audiosuite processing" for this reason! Also, you can just use a 24bit dither when you go from 32 to 24bit at mastering stage as needed (if you are providing the master).

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- **More samples (slices) per second equals a better representation of the analog waveform.** Within half the band of the sample rate (say up to 22.05k for 44.1k) this is demonstrably not true. I know that is confounding, but digital and information theory is basically miraculous
- **We can hear/feel/sense sounds above 20k.** We truly really cannot and if you experiment with significant energy above 20k you’ll actually see problems creep in for electronics and speakers etc. Information above 20k is not our friend (space for harmonic information to live without aliasing back excepted)
- **Working at multiples of 44.1k is better because the sample rate conversion will work better.** This used to be a little bit true a long time ago but hasn’t been for a long time. Use the SRC in iZotope RX on it’s stock preset to 44.1 and you are in pretty good shape
- **Digital EQs work better at higher sample rates because of cramping.** Cramping was an esoteric problem with older digital EQs that looked bad on analyzers but never actually sounded very bad. It’s a solved problem nowadays with most EQs.
- **Video and film is at 48k so we must start there.** Yes film and TV still work at 48k (although YouTube specs 44.1 now) but I have sent a million tracks for sync at 44.1 and it gets dropped in with SRC and away we go

author: austenballard
content:
It seems like your square wave trick should be a best practice, since it's definitely not just master bus PDC that can throw things off. The other person's effects, or their sample rate, or working across DAWs could all contribute to misalignment.

What's your method for doing the square waves? Is there a particular plugin you like for generating the tones? Is there a specific 'low frequency' that works best?

author: austenballard
content: Do you think it would make sense to set up a template with a MIDI instrument set to play eighth-note sine waves at a given frequency in the pre-roll, or is entrusting the job to an instrument asking for trouble? I'm thinking of that as a possible quick way to have a sync track available at all times across LPX, PT and Ableton

Only to go listen later and find the take was lackluster.

author: BoozleBAM
content: This has been on my mind lately, so I just figured I should run it across: I was being mentored (mixing) by this guy who I respect tremendously. He was always telling me that I need to replace my plugins (have been using free plugins for the longest) and suggested that I start with Waves and some of the UAD offerings. So, I went ahead and downloaded all the Waves counterparts (UAD wouldn't work on my computer for some reason) to my stable of free plugins and did a mix that way. At first I really liked it, but then the sound of the Waves stuff began to wear on me for some reason. That's the only way I can describe it - The sound started to wear on me. So, now I'm back to using my free plugins and liking mixing again. All that to say: Is there any reason I shouldn't use free plugins?? I have zero knowledge of what's going on "under the hood" of all this stuff. Zero technological prowess in that regard whatsoever. The only way i know how to tell if something is "better" than the other is by feeling, I suppose. So, yeah. And all these paid plugins, I mean... it's a lot of money. Thanks, ya'll.

I'd hate to go back to it because the 6i6 is just so bloody feature rich, but if I have to, I will - My mixes translated seamlessly when mixing through that thing... Comping drums soon! yay!!

author: rawssx
content: also isn’t a mic and a preamp also the industry standard? but d4vd made a billboard no.1 (banger) on his iphone recorded thru his earphone’s mic and still makes/records and releases songs just thru his phone using bandlab. Goes to show a good song is a good song and if one knows how to mix and knows what sounds good, thats the end. At the end of the day, music is a medium to translate feelings, and whatever works for you is the best.

author: Eric Martin
content: I use the plugin alliance one, and the old avid plug, both work well, maybe don’t sound perfect but it’s distortion

author: Zack Hames
content:
Here’s gain staging in a nut shell: don’t clip. In pro tools I try to keep all my faders at 0 or below. Seems to play nice and I don’t ever go back at the end of my mix to push everything down.

Make sure you aren’t clipping within plugins either. Fabfilter pro-Q 3 is notoriously nasty sounding when clipped.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Start with a fresh slate on a format you choose rather than whatever they give you

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: best to start with a clean slate

content: I know we've discussed this before, but what are some good work arounds for the silicon native vs. Rosetta trouble in Pro Tools? I have a couple favs that run really well on my M3 max when in Native, but are prone to crashing/stalling sessions when in Rosetta. Then vice versace, a few favs that aren't yet available in native, so I've loaded them as VST's with something like Waves's "StudioRack" but that's admitedly not my favorite option...

author: spectrummasters
content: I’m fascinated with phase and waves . I expect this might all be familiar to you but it seems there’s some handy info about phase and audio here https://mycourses.aalto.fi/pluginfile.php/666520/course/section/128564/Jon%20Fagerstr%C3%B6m_1929997_assignsubmission_file_AAT_Seminar_paper_Phase_Equalization_JF_FINAL.pdf?time=1558421096226#:~:text=Phase%20equalizers%20are%20filters%20that,response%20of%20a%20given%20system.

author: spectrummasters
content: Do you have izotope eq ? There’s a setting in the preferences that says something like “show all curves “ click on it and it adds a time display into the graphic on the gui

author: spectrummasters
content: It’s an interesting tool to be able to slide between eq types and not have to switch them as in FabFilter .

author: spectrummasters
content: I think this interest is a natural progression for many of us . I’m a science grad , electrician and above all a  musician . Long term probably the real driving force for my love and learning in engineering is my musical side and wanting to understand waves . Audio and electrical engineering and their marriage and understanding of one to inform the other  is probably my main fascination in life these days (along with the maths and physics of it ) .

author: Zack Hames
content: Also, if the music is supposed to be listened to loud….do some EQ moves with the speakers up a bit. I find EQ moves translate better when I mix with some decent volume. Mixing quiet makes everything so out of balance for me especially low end and high end

author: Jemody
content: Honestly I just played around with stock plugins since those usually have everything you need

author: Josh
content: And just because they’re dark doesn’t mean the high end isn’t analytical. I could finally hear exactly what my de-esser was doing and low passing became more important. But as far the “profile” of the high end, it rarely translates for me if Im sent a session where I have to really sculpt the high end material in it.

author: BoozleBAM
content: I have a question: I'm interested in creating some "ambient" or more "instrumental"/ experimental soundscapes. The only thing is that I HATE using keyboards - Synths, keyboards, just NOT_MY_THING. Don't ask me why, but my instruments need to have some "vibrato"/ variation element to them; guitars, bass, drums, etc - "real" instruments... Anybody got recs for things I can experiment with to really create some more wild sonic landscapes? I tried using one of those guitar "synth" pedals, but those are still restricted in the way they interact with or translate the vibration of the strings -still mostly clicking in-between "droning" sounds, more or less.
